title: Question 3
prompt: Which elements of geography were most important to the combat between the Germans and the Soviet Union in 1941?
description: Click the  <u>one best answer</u> to each question.
feedback:
The winter weather in Moscow and the distance that German supply lines had to travel were both important to combat between Germany and the Soviet Union in 1941. Weather and distance were important factors.

Before the German invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941, the Soviet government ignored warnings about the German buildup of troops, and Germany initially overwhelmed the Soviet armies, forcing the surrender of millions of Soviet troops. The German army advanced, reaching Leningrad by September 1941. German troops approached Moscow in early December. The troops, though, were not equipped for the winter and had advanced beyond their supply lines, which were vulnerable due to 1,000-mile distance between Moscow and Berlin. The Soviet Union launched a major counterattack, pushing the German forces back from Moscow. After several weeks, the Germans were able to establish a new front east of Smolensk.
